abstract:
Barnes & Noble, the nation’s largest book chain, said on Thursday that it was considering spinning off its Nook e-reader division in an effort to help the nascent — and expensive — digital business grow, report Julie Bosman and Michael J. de La Merced in The New York Times.

They write that while the company has made quick work of capturing almost 30 percent of the e-book market in two years, the rise of digital reading has increased the pressure on it to devise a winning long-term strategy against Amazon, which still dominates e-book sales.

Sales of Nook devices for the nine-week holiday period ending Dec. 31 were up 70 percent over the same period a year earlier, Barnes & Noble said Thursday, while all Nook-related sales, including devices, accessories and digital content, were up 43 percent.

Brian X. Chen, technology reporter for The Times, writes in an accompanying article that the Apple iPad has yet to wipe out the e-readers like the Nook, though that was the popular prediction. He also reports that I.H.S. iSuppli, a research company, estimates that Barnes & Noble has 13 percent of the e-reader market after two years in the business, versus 67 percent for Amazon.

The Epicenter blog noted:

So what’s the problem? Even though Nook set records, and overall retail sales for the holidays were up, sales of the Nook Simple Touch e-reader were disappointing. A price cut from $140 to $100 to match the new Kindle Touch couldn’t give the six-month-old Touch enough of a boost going into the holidays.
Business Insider was highly skeptical. Pascal-Emmanuel Gobry wrote:
Nook’s only advantage in the market is Barnes & Noble’s retail: that the Nook is heavily promoted in B&N stores, and B&N still has heft in the book business to get publishing deals.
He concluded, “In the long term, Nook is doomed. It has been a valiant effort, but Kindle economics are too powerful.”

headline.main: Daily Report: Barnes & Noble Considers Spinning Off Its Nook Unit
